thread.title: ‘The Honeycomb Trilogy’ Offers a Ticket for Binge Watchers
thread.title_full: ‘The Honeycomb Trilogy’ Offers a Ticket for Binge Watchers - WSJ

author: Lizzie Simon
title: ‘The Honeycomb Trilogy’ Offers a Ticket for Binge Watchers
text:
0 COMMENTS ‘The Honeycomb Trilogy’ The Gym at Judson
243 Thompson St.
(866) 811-4111
gideonth.com
Previews begin Oct. 13
Mac Rogers’s critically acclaimed triptych follows one family over a 10-year period as their lives are upended by an extraterrestrial invasion. For those who want to binge watch all three works, “Advance Man,” “Blast Radius” and “Sovereign” will be performed consecutively on Saturdays and Sundays, with Guy & Gallard offering five different meal options, each named for a character.
ENLARGE Silas Riener's ‘Blue Name’ Photo: Silas Riener ‘Blue Name’ The Chocolate Factory Theater
5-49 49th Ave.
Long Island City, N.Y.
(718) 482-7069
chocolatefactorytheater.org
Oct. 14-28
Silas Riener’s program of solos was created during 18 months of investigating “what it means to dance in front of people and to share an experience of being alive in the world.” Mr. Riener, who appears on the cover of Dance Magazine this month with his partner in life and in dance, Rashaun Mitchell, won a 2012 Bessie Award for his solo performance in Merce Cunningham’s “Split Sides.”
ENLARGE César Alvarez and Sammy Tunis sing in ‘Futurity.’ Photo: Julieta Cervantes ‘Futurity’ The Connelly Theater
220 E. 4th St.
(212) 352-3101
sohorep.org
In previews, opens Oct. 20
One of the most anticipated musicals off-Broadway this season comes by way of Ars Nova and Soho Rep, two of the city’s most adventurous producers of emerging artists. César Alvarez stars in and has written the book, lyrics and, with his band The Lisps, the music for this “avant-Americana musical” about a Civil War soldier and a mathematical genius. In recent years, Mr. Alvarez composed the music for such award-winning experimental works as Branden Jacob-Jenkins’s “An Octoroon” and Lear deBessonet’s “Good Person of Szechwan.” Soho Rep artistic director Sarah Benson is at the helm.
‘Dada Woof Papa Hot’ Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater
150 W. 65th St.
(212) 239-6200
lct.org
Previews begin Oct. 15
Peter Parnell’s new play, set in New York, follows two gay couples, played by Patrick Breen, Alex Hurt, Stephen Plunkett and John Benjamin Hickey, as they navigate their lives as parents. Scott Ellis directs.
‘Hir’ Playwrights Horizons
416 W. 42nd St.
(212) 279-4200
phnyc.org
Previews begin Oct. 16
Taylor Mac, who has won acclaim as a performance artist, director, actor, performance artist and songwriter, has penned this drama about a woman, played by Kristine Nielsen, liberating herself from an oppressive marriage. Niegel Smith, the newly appointed artistic director of the Flea Theater, is at the helm.
